Description: Mould-made pottery plastic oil-lamp in the form of a head of a bearded satyr wearing an ivy-wreath, or the comic mask of Silenus. Large filling-hole on the upper part of the head, small wick-hole on the lower part of the head. The applied vertical band handle is missing. Covered with a red slip.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Close parallel in black slip from Alexandria dated 2nd century BC (Bailey 1988, 455, Q577 ter). Like other mould-made lamps, these were produced in red and black slipped variants (Bailey 1975, 278) and could, like others in this class, be 1st century BC.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.063) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4604 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
